page.title: 12Local history of Saline Fife
page.content: There is very little written in history books about Saline. When it is referred to,it is named Saulyne,hence the older villagers still use this pronunciation. Saline is said to have derived it's name from the Gaelic word meaning 'great' or 'big'. With the 'great' or 'big' thing locally being Saline Hill,it is surmised that Saline is named after the hill. The remains of Killernie Castle are to be found to the east of Saline. It is thought that travelling monks may have used the Castle with it's proximity to a spring. Amenities in general have improved in Saline over the years,but maps dated 1853 show Saline to have had in those days a reading room,a cricket ground and a Police Station. These amenities are no longer in Saline.
